body: One of the main changes brought in by the GDPR is the addition or enhancement of a number of individual rights. These rights are particularly relevant if the lawful basis for processing personal data is either through consent or contract.
title: Individual rights

_items.title: Right to be informed
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to be informed about how personal data about them is collected and used.

This information should be presented in a privacy notice. This should be presented to the individual when data is collected, in clear, concise language and be easily accessible.

_items.title: Right to access
_items.body:
The GDPR gives people the right of access to get confirmation from controllers about whether or not personal data about them is being processed, and, where that is the case, access to the following information:

  • the purposes of the processing
  • the categories of personal data concerned
  • who the data is shared with, including transfers to other territories
  • how long the data will be retained
  • details of other individual rights and how to enact those rights
  • the existence of automated decision making

While the right to access is present in the Data Protection Act (DPA), the GDPR makes organisations support the right to access without charge.

Further, the controller shall provide a copy of the personal data within a month of the request and in an electronic format where possible.

_items.title: Right to rectification
_items.body: Individuals have the right to have personal data corrected if it is inaccurate or incomplete. Where necessary, controllers must also correct any copies shared with others.

_items.title: Right to be forgotten
_items.body:
The right to be forgotten (or the right to data erasure) entitles an individual to direct the controller to erase personal data about them, cease further sharing of the data, and potentially  halt processing of the data by third parties.

Data must be erased if:

  • it is no longer relevant to the original purpose for processing
  • no lawful basis exists for the data to be held and processed
  • an individual withdraws consent

_items.title: Right to restrict processing
_items.body:
Individuals have a right to ‘block’ or suppress processing of personal data.

Such rights can be exercised when:

  • the accuracy of the personal data is contested
  • where the individual has objected to the processing (only in the case of performance of a public task or legitimate interest)
  • the processing is unlawful
  • the data is needed for future reference but should no longer be processed

_items.title: Right to data portability
_items.body:
The right to data portability allows individuals to obtain and reuse their personal data across different services. It allows them to copy or transfer personal data easily from one IT environment to another in secure way, without hindrance to usability. The right of portability only applies:

  • to personal data directly provided by an individual
  • where the processing is based on the individual’s consent or for the performance of a contract
  • when processing is carried out by automated means

_items.title: Right to withdraw consent (if applicable)
_items.body:
If the lawful basis for processing is based on having consent, the individual has the right to withdraw that consent at any time. 

The process of withdrawing consent must be as easy as giving consent in the first place.

_items.title: Right to object
_items.body:
People have the right to object to you processing data about them. The right to object is not an absolute right and it applies only in certain circumstances. If one of these circumstances is met, you must stop processing data about them. The valid circumstances are:

  • when personal data is used for direct marketing (in this case the right is absolute as a data subject can object at any time)
  • when data is used for research or statistical purposes, unless the processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest (e.g. in health research)
  • the data is processed based on public or legitimate interests

If you wish to continue processing you will need to demonstrate you have compelling legitimate interest that overrides the individual’s rights and freedoms.

_items.title: Right to not be subject solely to automated decision making
_items.body:
Individuals have the right to not be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling.

Automated processing can be carried out if the decision is:

  • necessary for the entry into or performance of a contract
  • authorised in law
  • based on the individual’s explicit consent

In all cases individuals must be informed about the automated processing and be able to request human intervention or challenge a decision.

body: If you are working with personal information in your role, here’s a short set of questions that can help ensure compliance with the GDPR.
title: Practical steps

_items.title: 1. Establish scope
_items.body:
Do you process personal data?

What types of personal data do you process?

Who do you share that data with, inside or outside the EU?

Are you a controller, a processor or both?

_items.title: 2. Establish lawful basis
_items.body: For each processing activity, which lawful basis justifies the processing of the personal data?

_items.title: 3. Check your data lifecycle
_items.body:
Is 'privacy by design' core to all your data processing activities involving personal data?

Have you carried out a Data Protection Impact Assessment where necessary?

Do you have appropriate contracts with processors to ensure compliance?

Are your processes documented (where necessary)?

Do you have a tightly controlled data retention and deletion policy relating to personal data?

_items.title: 4. Is the organisation ready to support the GDPR?
_items.body:
Do you have a data protection officer (if required)?

Do you have procedures to rapidly identify and respond to data breaches?

Does your sector have a code of conduct to help with GDPR compliance?

_items.title: 5. Supporting individuals rights
_items.body:
Do you have a clear privacy notice that informs individuals about the collection and use of personal data as well as rights under the GDPR?

Do you have processes that support an individual’s rights?

body: Organisations who breach the GDPR may face significant consequences including:
title: Threats

_items.title: Monetary fines
_items.body:
Significant penalties can be imposed on organisations who breach the GDPR, including fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of a company’s turnover (whichever is larger) per breach.

This is a huge increase from the previous £500,000 fines imposed by the Data Protection Act in the UK.

_items.title: Corrective orders
_items.body:
The supervisory authority may also issue a corrective order that an organisation must comply with. 

Corrective powers include, amongst other things: issuing warnings; ordering compliance with a individual's requests to exercise their rights; ordering compliance with the GDPR; and, ordering restrictions on data processing activities including the permanent deletion of personal data.

In the UK, the Information Commisioner’s Office (ICO) publishes information about actions it has taken against organisations that have not complied with the act.

_items.title: Reputational damage
_items.body:
In addition to monetary fines and actions, breaching the GDPR may result in significant reputational damage. 

According to a survey of 1,350 business decision makers, the Risk:Value report from NTT Security that loss of confidence was the main concern of breaching the GDPR (55% of respondents), followed by damage to brand/reputation (51%) and direct financial loss (43%).

body: There are many opportunities that arise as a result of the GDPR including:
title: Impacts of the GDPR

_items.title: More effective use of data
_items.body:
Unsolicited electronic marketing can be undertaken if the person you're targeting has given you their permission. However such blanket approaches are often ineffective, costly and time consuming. 

More effective use of personal data could help target specific customers where it would be in their legitimate interest to hear about certain products or services.

_items.title: Reduction in data storage costs
_items.body:
Better management and control over personal data in an organisation can help deduplicate customer records as well as identify data that is no longer required. 

As well as being able to reduce storage costs significantly, deduplication can also help identify links between products that are offered and which customers purchase a multitude of products.

_items.title: Reducing risk
_items.body:
Understanding what personal data an organisation holds and how it is processed helps reduce risk of such data falling into the wrong hands. 

Practices encouraged by the GDPR like data minimisation and deduplication help ensure that personal data is securely managed and disposed of when no longer required.

body:
Privacy notices are one of the most visible aspects of GDPR adoption. 

Individuals must be informed clearly about how personal data is processed and how they can exercise their rights over the data. This information must be presented to the individual at point of collection.

The privacy notice should clearly outline:

  • the purpose and lawful basis of the processing
  • the name of the controller and contact details of the data protection officer
  • details of data transfers to third countries and safeguards
  • the retention period or criteria used to determine the retention period
  • the individual’s rights
  • the existence of automated decision making, including profiling and information about how decisions are made, their significance and their consequences

Where data is not collected directly from the data subject, the privacy notice must also include the types of data collected and be presented to the individual as near to the point of collection as possible.
title: Privacy notices

body:
Controllers are liable for their compliance with the GDPR and must only appoint processors who can provide ‘sufficient guarantees’ that the requirements of the GDPR will be met and people's rights protected.

Processors must only act on the documented instructions of a controller and must not engage another processor without prior specific or general written authorisation of the controller. This said, processors are still required to comply with the law and contest any instruction from the controller that may result in illegal processing.

The processor must also fully comply with controllers' instructions to delete or return all personal data to the controller at the end of the contract.
title: Obligations of the processor

body:
The world we live in today is vastly different from that of 1995 when data protection laws in the European Union were last updated (1998 in the case of the Data Protection Act in the UK). The GDPR is a new regulation that is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency. The GDPR also provides standardisation of data protection laws across all European member states, making it easier for organisations to provide services to people in the EU.

From 25 May 2018, existing data protection regulations in the European Union will be replaced by the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

body:
This lesson provides an overview of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the key differences from the existing data protection regulations. After completion, you should able to work more confidently with the requirements of the GDPR.

This lesson explores:

  • What is the GDPR and why it is needed?
  • What is the scope of the GDPR?
  • Organisation obligations
  • Individual rights
  • The GDPR and privacy notices
  • Practical steps
displayTitle: Introduction to the General Data Protection Regulation
title: Introduction to the General Data Protection Regulation

_items.title: Data protection officers
_items.body:
The GDPR requires the appointment of a data protection officer (DPO) if you are a public authority or if you carry out certain types of processing activities involving large scales of personal data or special categories of personal data. Other organisations can appoint DPOs too.

DPOs monitor internal compliance, inform and advise on your data protection obligations, provide advice regarding Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs) and act as a contact point for the organisation both internally and externally.

The DPO must be independent, an expert in data protection, adequately resourced, and report to the highest management level.

_items.title: Data breaches
_items.body:
The GDPR introduces a duty on all organisations to report any serious data breach to the relevant supervisory authority.

A personal data breach means a breach of security leading to the unlawful destruction, loss, alteration, unauthorised disclosure of, or access to, personal data. This includes both accidental and deliberate breaches.

You should ensure you have robust breach detection, investigation and internal reporting procedures in place. This will facilitate decision making about whether or not you need to notify the relevant supervisory authority and the affected individuals.

Breach notification is mandatory where a data breach is likely to result in a risk for the rights and freedoms of individuals. You must do this within 72 hours of becoming aware of the breach. Under certain conditions, you must also inform the individuals affected.

You must also keep a record of any personal data breaches, regardless of whether you are required to notify.

body: The following are examples of when the GDPR does and does not apply.
displayTitle: Example scenarios for when the GDPR applies
title: Example scenarios for when the GDPR applies

_items.title: US citizens orders from EU online store
_items.body:
A US citizen orders something from an online store for a company established in the EU.

The site collects personal information.

The GDPR applies

_items.title: EU citizen orders from US online store
_items.body:
A French citizen orders online from a merchant based in the US, who has made no effort to target their services to anyone outside of the US. All payments must be in USD.

Just because they agree to ship the merchandise to the EU does not, by itself, put the merchant in-scope for the GDPR, even if they do collect personal data.

The GDPR does not apply
_items.strapline: EU citizen orders from US online store

_items.title: Individual interacts with organisation established in EU
_items.body:
A Nigerian citizen subscribes to an online service for a company established in the EU.

The GDPR applies
_items.strapline: Individual interacts with organisation established in EU

_items.title: Privacy by design
_items.body:
'Privacy by design' is a legal requirement. It requires organisations to consider people’s privacy from the start of the design of any system or service and not just bolt it on at the end.

Where data processing is likely to result in a high risk to individuals, a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) is required under the GDPR.

A DPIA helps you to:

  • describe the nature, scope, context and purposes of the processing
  • assess necessity, proportionality and compliance measures
  • identify and assess risks to individuals
  • identify any additional measures to mitigate those risks

_items.title: Contracts with data processors
_items.body:
It is highly likely that a controller will use a number of processors to not just store but also collect and analyse data.

Whenever a controller uses a processor it needs to have a written contract in place with that processor.

Controllers are liable for their compliance with the GDPR and must only appoint processors who can provide ‘sufficient guarantees’ that the requirements of the GDPR will be met and the people’s rights protected.

Processors must only act on the documented instructions of a controller. They do however have some direct responsibilities under the GDPR, such as having to give notification of data breaches, and being subject to fines or other sanctions if they do not comply.

_items.title: Records of processing
_items.body:
The GDPR contains explicit provisions requiring you to document your processing activities (what you do with personal data). 

As well as being a legal requirement, documenting your processing activities can support good data governance and help you demonstrate your compliance with other aspects of the GDPR.

The amount of documentation required depends on the size of your organisation and the activities it carries out.

Documentation can help in many areas including:

  • establishing the extent of personal data your organisation holds
  • establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data
  • writing clearer privacy statements
  • fulfilling your obligations to share the data with others including those the data is about
  • records keeping including which territory data is stored in, records of consent and Data Protection Impact Assessment reports
  • responding to queries from your supervisory authority (eg ICO)
  • notification and management of data breaches

_items.title: Ensuring transfers are legitimate
_items.body:
The GDPR makes it much easier to transfer data within the EU than before.

Transfers outside of the EU may be made:

  • to locations that the European Commission decide provide an adequate level of protection
  • to organisations where appropriate protection is provided through contractual clauses
  • with the individual's informed consent
  • where it is absolutely necessary to fulfil the lawful basis

_items.title: Data retention and security
_items.body:
The GDPR requires personal data to be processed securely. This includes protection against unauthorised or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction or damage. It requires that appropriate technical or organisational measures are used.

Additionally, the GDPR requires that personal data only be retained while there is a lawful basis for doing so, such as needing to have proof of an expired contract or employment. It might not be necessary to keep the complete record for this, rather only a part. This is a practice known as data minimisation that can also help minimise risk.

_items.title: Data minimisation
_items.body: The practice of data minimisation is about limiting personal data collection, storage, usage and retention to only the data that is relevant and absolutely necessary for carrying out the purpose for which the data is processed.

body:
The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR applies to the processing of personal data about individuals who are in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, if it either:

  • offers goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  • monitors individual's behaviour within the EU
title: Territorial scope

body:
The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner.

There are six lawful bases outlined in the GDPR. At least one must apply. Without a lawful basis, it is illegal to collect and process personal data. 

Additionally, with the exception of consent, if you could reasonably perform your tasks without collecting personal data then the lawful basis does not apply. If you could provide the same service without collecting personal data, but still want to collect that data, you have to get consent from the individual.
title: Establishing the lawful basis for processing personal data

_items.title: Performance of contract
_items.body:
You can rely on this lawful basis if you need to process personal data to fulfil contractual obligations with an individual, or if they have asked you to take specific steps before entering into a contract.

For example, you can process a potential customer’s personal data to provide a quote for fitting double glazing on a house and the subsequent fitting.

_items.title: Legal obligation
_items.body:
You can process personal data if the processing is necessary for you to comply with the law. Contractual obligations you have with third parties do not count as a legal basis for processing.

For example, an employer needs to process personal data to comply with employment law. In financial services, personal data can be legally processed if ’strictly necessary for the purposes of preventing fraud.’

If you are processing personal data on the basis of a legal obligation, the individual has no right to data portability, no right to object; and no right to erasure.

However, an individual does have a right to erasure if the legal obligation has expired. For example, if someone left the employment of a company, there is unlikely to be a legal obligation for the employer to keep data about that person after a few years.

_items.title: Vital interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary to protect someone’s life.

This does not apply if you can reasonably protect the person’s vital interests in another less intrusive way.

This lawful basis also does not apply for health data or other special category data if the individual is capable of giving consent.

_items.title: Public task
_items.body:
You can process personal data if it is necessary for you to perform a task in the public interest or for your official functions, where the task or function has a clear basis in law.

For example, private water companies are likely to be able to rely on the public task basis even if they do not fall within the definition of a public authority, because they have legal powers to provide clean water, which is in the public interest.

_items.title: Legitimate interests
_items.body:
You can process personal data if doing so is in the legitimate interests of the individual, third parties, or society. 'Legitimate interests' is the most flexible lawful basis for processing personal data, but you cannot assume it will always be the most appropriate.

If you choose to rely on legitimate interests as the lawful basis for processing, you take on extra responsibility for ensuring people’s rights and interests are fully considered and protected. You may need to carry out a balancing test that examines if the individual’s interests override the legitimate interest and detail this in your privacy notice.

Legitimate interests’ is likely to be most appropriate where personal data is used in ways individuals would reasonably expect and which have a minimal privacy impact. Even where there is an impact on individuals, it may still apply if you can show there is an even more compelling benefit to the processing and the impact is justified. For example, if a customer could be offered a cheaper or better version of a product, then direct marketing may well be of legitimate interest to that individual.

_items.title: Consent
_items.body:
Under the GDPR, individuals must be informed about how personal data will be used and how consent can be given for each use. You cannot ask for open-ended consent to use data however you want to. 

A good example comes when performing a medical procedure on a patient. In this case, consent must granted in full knowledge of the possible consequences. This is a practice known as 'informed consent'.

Gaining consent must be through clear affirmative action, such as a button press or an opt-in tick box. Hidden conditions and opt-out options where no action is required does not constitute clearly obtained consent under the GDPR.

Additionally, the individual must be able to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The process for withdrawing consent must be as easy to complete as that for giving consent.

body: What is the definition of personal data in the GDPR?
title: What is personal data?

_items.text: Any information relating to an identified or identifiable person
Any data owned by an individual

_feedback.correct:

Under the GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person.

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

body: Which individuals does the GDPR apply to?
title: The scope of the GDPR

_items.text: All individuals interacting with an organisation operating in the EU, regardless of nationality
All EU citizens interacting with any company worldwide

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The GDPR will apply to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

The GDPR will also apply to the processing of personal data in the EU by an organisation not established in the EU, where the activities relate to either:

  1. Offering goods or services within EU (irrespective of whether payment is required)
  2. Monitoring of individuals behaviour as far as their behaviour takes place within the EU

This means that even if a company has no physical base in the EU, the GDPR may still apply if goods and services are offered to those located within the EU.

On this basis you do not need to be an EU citizen for the GDPR to apply. Anyone located in the EU interacting with services offered in the EU is in scope of the GDPR.

body:
The GDPR replaces the existing data protection regulations throughout Europe. The GDPR is designed to provide a greater level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals through accountability and transparency.

The GDPR applies to the processing of all personal data by organisations in the EU, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the EU or not.

Significant penalties and orders can be imposed on organisations who breach the GDPR, including fines of up to 20 million euros or 4% of a company’s turnover (whichever is larger).

One of main changes brought in by the GDPR is the addition or enhancement of a number of individual rights.

The GDPR requires everyone to process personal data lawfully and communicate this basis clearly. This is done through an organisations privacy notice; the most visible part of the GDPR.

For more details on the GDPR we recommend the dedicated EU GDPR website and the Information Commissioner Office guide for data protection laws in the UK. If you reside in another EU member state, then you should also check for additional data protection regulations specific to this state.
title: Summary

body:
There are two main roles that organisations play in the processing of personal data. 

Controller

A controller is any body that, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.

Processor

A processor is any body that processes personal data on behalf of the controller.

body: There are four different types of personal data that are in scope of GDPR:
title: Personal data
instruction: Explore each of these in more detail below.

_items.title: Personal data
_items.body:
Under the GDPR, 'personal data' means any information relating to an identified or identifiable person. 

This covers any piece of information that can result in the identification of a person, either directly or indirectly.

This could be via any identifier, such as a name, email, address, phone number, an identification number, an online identifier (including IP address) or factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that person.

However data of these types might not always be personally identifiable. For example the name John Smith is very common, however when combined with other data, such as date of birth and address this then becomes identifiable. Remember that names are not needed to identify someone - you probably don't know the names of all your neighbours but you can identify them.

_items.title: Special categories of personal data
_items.body:
Special categories of personal data (previously referred to as sensitive personal data) merit higher protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.

These categories include:

  • racial or ethnic origin
  • political opinions
  • religious or philosophical beliefs
  • trade union membership
  • genetic and biometric data (new in the GDPR)
  • physical or mental health or conditions
  • sex life or sexual orientation

_items.title: Criminal convictions data
_items.body:
Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures can only be carried out:

  • under the control of official authority
  • when the processing is authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for people's rights and freedoms

Any comprehensive register of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.

_items.title: Data about children
_items.body:
Data about children must be treated carefully as they may be less aware of the risks involved. 

When consent is required for the use of data about someone under 16 years old, that consent must be given by a holder of parental responsibility for that child.

When Member States create their own data protection laws (such as the UK), they may specify a lower age, but it cannot be lower than 13 years.
